1.words: Okay, we are recording. Good morning everybody. Thank you so much for participating in the Storytellers Project, sponsored by an organization called Cortico and the New York City Department of Health. My name is David [Surname] and I work with the Borough Park Jewish Community Council on their COVID Disparities grant. So why are we here? We're here because the pandemic is now actually almost, we're approaching it the three year anniversary in March. And, wow, that's really a long time, and yourselves, I'm sure have really struggled and countered and managed to get through the pandemic and we're probably very deeply affected by it. The sponsors of this activity, and I share this belief as well, is that really to understand something you have to talk to the people most directly affected. That means the citizens of our city who... Everyone has a story to tell, an important story that we can learn a lot from regarding just so many different parts of this whole COVID pandemic experience. So that's what we're going to do today. We're going to just have some questions and you're just going to freely talk about your experiences. Nothing to be nervous about, just talk about what happened to you. And that will be very, very meaningful for this project and for others to hear, to listen. Your responses are being recorded and they will go into a library with hundreds of others and people, I don't know what they're calling it, the voices of COVID or people speak about COVID, but I'm sure it'll be very interesting to stakeholders and getting a deeper understanding of really how people were affected by COVID. So I'm going to read a consent statement that's part of this procedure and so that everybody's on the same page and you signed your consent form. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to the New York City Public Health Corp to use the recording in accordance with its mission. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve our understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. Okay. I just have to get that business out of the way. I'm wondering if I should sit closer. Just not taking any chances. [inaudible] Just a little closer. You all are really close. So our first activity is everyone just go around and introduce yourself and there's a little exercise called PIES, P I E S, where you just talk about something. It could be physically, intellectually, emotionally, or spiritually what you're feeling today. So that's just what they call it, an icebreaker. That's the new, you always have to have an icebreaker. So when you start a meeting... And also say, I agree. I agree, when you're done introducing that you agree to participate and you heard the reading, the sentence I just read.

71.words: I think ultimately we look up to various different leaders in our community and with that leadership position comes that responsibility to take this on and be that place for our community to go to. Which we realized with COVID there was a very big vacuum and that's something that really needed to be filled. We needed somebody to really take on health leadership, which really, really was not in our community. We had [inaudible] and everybody has their doctors, but fortunately we never had a pandemic like COVID19. There was never something that shut us down for so long and really made everything grind to a stop. So we never had something that we needed everybody united against.

96.words: I just think the benefits in this specific case don't outweigh the negatives with the COVID vaccine. You have the same argument with the flu shot every year, that the flu shot doesn't specifically counter that year's strain of flu, but majority of people don't have any side effects when they take the flu shot, which is why people get it. The COVID vaccine, there are some side effects that can really impact a person's life, and for the amount of times that people have gotten it after they got the vaccine, I don't see that it's worth it. Plus the boosters and plus all that, I didn't take it. I don't think the benefit of it possibly preventing COVID, when I don't think I ever had it yet, but maybe I did, I don't know. I don't think so. I never knew that I had it. I didn't feel that I had it. I don't see a major benefit in taking the vaccine, because you're not getting a sure foolproof assurance that you're not going to get COVID with it, and then you still have to get, I don't know how many boosters after. 193.words: That's the question. What did we learn?

194.words: What we learned? First of all, I think we're learning now. There's a lot of emotional backlash. Even more in a way than physical backlash from COVID and from, I don't know if you could say the way it was dealt with, but just the fact that you're taking a community that their basic way of life is interacting with each other every single week and always. And then you dump in all the holidays and then it becomes three times a week and the men go to pray three times a day. You're taking such a community, you're just telling them stay in your houses. The emotional backlash of being told to not go anywhere and not talk to anyone and not do anything, I think is coming out now more than before. Because everyone's just dealing with the very real physical ramifications, which were people getting sick, people dying. People were still recovering from that until now, but now it's two years, it's around two years past that.
